awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Kevin Moeller of the Department of Chemistry at Washington University in St. Louis is exploring the utility of electrochemistry as a tool for building the complex molecules that are frequently of interest to the pharmaceutical and chemical industries. The program has two main goals. The first is to gain a better understanding of the highly reactive intermediates central to synthetic reactions that increase the functionality of organic molecules. The second is to build the chemical insight necessary for the larger synthetic chemistry community to take full advantage of electrochemical methods. The broader impacts of the work are both scientific and educational.  On the science front, the proposed electrochemistry holds great potential as a sustainable technique. The reactions can be run in a manner that uses sunlight (or any other clean source of electricity) as the only source of energy and generates no waste product. Such processes are both atom and energy economical. Because of these advantages, electrochemical methods are gaining in popularity, and numerous scientists from around the world enlist Professor Moeller to aide their own efforts to capitalize on the reactions. On the education front, the project supports the training of young scientists in both chemical and electrochemical techniques, the development of undergraduate laboratory experiments that expose students to their first electrochemical reactions, and the continued implementation of outreach activities that utilize zoo and science center educational programs to teach science to the general public.  

The science being pursued in this project capitalizes on mechanistic studies to both guide the development of new radical cation triggered cyclizations and illustrate how electrochemical methods can be used as synthetic tools. For example, recent observations that the removal of a second electron from a molecule plays a critical role in a successful cyclization reaction are being used to design new reactions that utilize this second oxidation step to both drive the processes to completion and to afford unique modes of reactivity. At the same time, new competition studies are being used to both probe the generality of these mechanistic findings, as well as to design new approaches to the synthesis of spirocyclic rings. New paired electrochemical methods, that take advantage of the reactions occurring at both electrodes in an electrochemical reaction, are being developed in order to maximize the energy economy of the processes. Each of these methods serves to illustrate, for the larger synthetic community, just how powerful electrochemical methods can be. As more synthetic chemists become interested in electrochemical reactions of their own design, the Moeller group remains poised to assist their efforts to implement them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: From pharmaceuticals, herbicides, pesticides, dyes and food preservatives to materials found in cell phones, tires, and plastics, to the development of modern diagnostics, our ability to make chemical compounds and materials frequently defines the quality of our lives and we meet challenges in the future. For this reason, the chemical industry remains one of the largest, most profitable industries in our nation.

While this industry continues to thrive, it is also faced with many challenges such as sustainability. Many of the chemical reactions utilized to make molecules and materials produce waste products that can have a strong negative impact on the environment. Oxidation reactions are among our most significant offenders along these lines because they require the formation of a byproduct in the same quantity as the desired product. The reactions are important and cannot be avoided because they are the only reactions that we have that allow us to increase the functionality of a molecule. So we use them, even though oxidation reactions are often defined as much by the waste products they produce as they are the synthetic transformations they accomplish.

For this reason, our NSF funded project has been looking at electrochemical oxidation reactions that use electricity to conduct the transformations, avoid the use of chemical oxidants, and channel the required reduction reaction to the formation of benign hydrogen gas. In addition, the reactions reverse the polarity of electron-rich functional groups in ways that make available entirely new avenues for synthesis. Yet while all of this has been known for a long time, the reactions proceed through highly reactive intermediates that we frequently know little about. So, how can we take full advantage of these potentially transformative reactions if we do not have a deep understanding of how the intermediates key to their success actually behave? Our work is focused on developing this understanding. One of the key discoveries made is that electrochemical reactions are frequently governed by steps that occur "downstream" of the initial electron-transfer reaction. This insight has allowed us to overcome barriers that were keeping our development of the reactions from reaching its full potential, a change that is now allowing us to explore new applications of the approach to synthetic challenges; a development that allows us to not only fix specific synthetic steps within a chemical sequence, but also to develop new, more efficient overall strategies to molecules. During this past budget period, we were also able to improve the sustainability of the reactions by demonstrating that the auxiliary reaction (generation of hydrogen above) can be used to make chemical reagents that can improve the sustainability of additional reactions in a synthetic sequence. We demonstrated just how general this strategy can be.

 

Broader Impact: The broader impact of the work conducted has been both scientific and educational in nature. On the scientific front, the work is making electrochemistry more accessible to the larger chemistry community. While electrochemistry is now more than ever being adopted by the larger synthetic community interested in new, more sustainable transformations, these efforts still only harness a fraction of what electrochemistry has to offer. With this in mind, the project focused on expanding examples of electrochemical methods to show how variations in the reactions can be used to introduce entirely new selectivity into chemical reactions, selectivity that cannot be accomplished using any chemical reagent. In this light, the work being conducted is continuing to play a critical role by defining for the larger community how to think about electrochemical processes. Of course, this knowledge is only useful if it is taught to others. For this reason, the project included a multi-prong educational effort to give seminars, to teach short courses on electrochemistry at both academic and industrial institutions and scientific meetings, to host visiting scientists in our labs so that they can learn electrochemical techniques, to answering questions on the phone and in person about electrochemical methods, and developing lab experiments that can be taught to younger students so that they have a familiarity with electrochemistry, and to provide outreach talks at retirement homes and other public forums. 

In addition to these efforts, we have been engaging younger children in hands-on experiments focused on nurturing in them a fascination with all aspects of science. Much of this effort has focused on developing curriculum for students who obtain their science education in non-traditional environments like home-school programs run by zoos and science centers. During this COVID-19 altered budget period, we have developed a new hands-on module for these efforts that connects electrochemistry with the synthesis of reactive intermediates that can be used to probe the word around us. Specifically, the project used electrochemistry to make a reactive intermediate that can teach young students the role Vitamin C play in protecting us from oxidants.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2022
Modified by: Kevin D Moeller
